comments: none
Live, virtual discussion sections
We met in person one time in front of sterling to eat snacks.
virtual discussion section

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A lot of new Hindi vocabulary, learned to read the Devanagari lipi along with its complex conjuncts, and learned many basic Hindi grammar topics.
I went from not being able to speak any Hindi and understanding a few words and sentences to being able to carry out a conversation by the end of the semester.

I learned introductory Hindi grammar and vocab, learned how to read and write Hindi, and was able to use the new constructions and vocabulary I learned in my spoken Hindi. My Hindi improved immensely over the course of the semester.
This was a brilliant class in which I learnt Hindi grammar, reading and conversation skills, and culture.
I developed reading, writing, and speaking skills in Hindi.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: One weakness of the course is the lack of structure during lectures and course organization on canvas. I think in order to improve the structure of lectures it's better to have a daily set of notes that can be looked at on canvas after the class If something was confusing in class. The current method is a student says something wrong at the beginning of class and the lecture becomes an impromptu speech afterward. That transition from casual conversation to formal lecture is also very fluid and can be confusing. I am not sure what kind of training can be done for canvas, it just seems that all my other classes are able to utilize the organization of canvas to make it very easy for their students to use.

The professors don't tell you very far in advance when your exams are or what subject matter your exams will be on. The course itself doesn't feel the most organized, but Swapna ji is very flexible and will work with you.

This is an awesome course. The material we go over is explained very well by Swapnaji and Chitraji, and the topics we learned about outside of grammar (i.e. Durga Puja, migrant workers, climate change, etc.) were interesting. I absolutely loved the skit and magaizne projects -- I had so much fun making my magazine and seeing how much my written Hindi and Hindi grammar had improved. A weakness might be that the assignments/material was not laid out from the beginning, but I understand how that might be hard given that we spent more/less time on certain topics than expected.

As the course progressed, it felt more structured and transition into various grammar structures made sense. Initially, it was a bit looser. I think it would be nice to work on vocabulary more. There is a lot of attention to teaching, and I appreciate that.
The Professor of this class is definitely its greatest strength. Her support and teaching and kindness was amazing.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of breakout rooms during the discussion section was well done.
I think the virtual seminars were great and discussion section was a good opportunity to practice.
This was a great course even on Zoom. I would have loved to have chai and samosas in person and be able to get to know my classmates, Swapnaji and Chitraji better, but it was nevertheless great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the class is usually small enough to allow for close-knit relationships in the class, it's almost like a seminar.

Yes, if you are interested in improving your Hindi at all then definitely take it! The instructors are very sweet and understanding of your situation, and you might have to work a little harder if you aren't fluent, but it isn't impossible to succeed.
Yes. This is a great course, Swapnaji and Chitraji are awesome, and I loved improving my Hindi.
I would recommend to any student with some understanding of Hindi and wishing to develop their knowledge of the subject.
